p: See Foucault’s (1980) term “power/knowledge,” arguing not that politics warps knowledge or rationality but that power and knowledge are inseparable from each other, and that the definition of a widely accepted truth is an effect of power. A variation on this argument about the social production of an accepted truth can be found in Navon and Eyal (2016), who propose that there are “networks of actors, devices, concepts, and institutional, discursive, and spatial arrangements that give the statement the value of truth—that make it thinkable, defensible, and actionable.”
